Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, the irritation is palpable. I can feel my own frustration rising again. "I'm tired" is the default response, the go-to excuse. I’m trying so hard to be understanding, and it feels like he's just dismissing me. It feels disrespectful, like he thinks he can just blow me off and I'll eventually give up.

I’m fighting the urge to just explode and yell, "No, you'll do them NOW!" That might feel good in the moment, but I know it will only escalate the situation and reinforce the negative pattern. I need to stay calm, stay grounded, and stick to my boundaries.

I'm also feeling a little defeated. This is harder than I thought. I really want to avoid the phone ban, but I also can't let him walk all over me. I'm questioning my approach. Am I being too soft? Too lenient? Should I just lay down the law?

But I also know that laying down the law, without any attempt at understanding or connection, will only push him further away. I need to find a balance between firmness and empathy. I need to remember that this is about more than just the dishes.

I'm also feeling a renewed sense of resolve. I can't let him win this one. Not because I want to win, but because I need to teach him that responsibilities matter, and that ignoring them has consequences. This is a life lesson, not just a chore.

I'm also noticing that he turned back to his PC. That's a clear sign that he's trying to shut me out, to avoid the conversation. It makes me feel like I'm talking to a brick wall. I need to find a way to break through that wall.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He's definitely feeling annoyed, maybe even angry. "I'm tired" is a way of shutting down the conversation, of avoiding responsibility without having to offer a legitimate explanation. He probably believes that if he just stonewalls me, I'll eventually give up and do the dishes myself, or let it slide until tomorrow.

He's probably feeling justified in his annoyance. He might genuinely be tired, or he might just be using it as an excuse. Either way, he feels like he deserves to relax and do what he wants, without being bothered by chores.

He's likely feeling a sense of power in defying me. He knows that his refusal is frustrating me, and that gives him a sense of control. It's a way of asserting his independence, even if it's in a passive-aggressive way.

He's probably also feeling a little bit trapped. He knows he should do the dishes, but he doesn't want to. He feels like he's being forced to do something he doesn't want to do, and that makes him resentful.

He's likely hoping that I'll just go away and leave him alone. He wants to avoid the confrontation, and he's banking on my aversion to conflict to make that happen. He is also thinking he can manipulate me.
# My response 
Okay, time to stay calm and clear. I'm going to stay in his room. Turning back to the PC is a classic avoidance tactic.

I'll say, still calmly but with a firmer tone, "I understand you're tired, but 'tomorrow' isn't going to work. The dishes need to be done tonight. Leaving them overnight makes them harder to clean, and it attracts bugs. It's not fair to the rest of the family."

(Pause, make eye contact, and wait for a response.)

If he continues to ignore me and focus on the computer, I'll say, "I'm not going to argue with you about this. I'm going to set a timer for one hour. If the dishes aren't done by then, your phone goes away for the night. I really don't want to do that, so let's avoid getting to that point."

Then, I'll add, "I'm going to leave you to it, but I'll be checking back in an hour. And if you want to talk about why this is so difficult for you, I'm here to listen. Seriously. But the dishes still need to get done."

Then, I'll get up and leave the room. I'll close the door behind me, but not slam it. This gives him space to process, but also reinforces the boundary. I need to follow through with the consequence if he doesn't comply. It's the only way to break this pattern.
User:
"No, Mom. NO. I just want to go to SLEEP. I told you I will do it TOMORROW." He is shouting at you. He stands up, and slams his hand on the desk, loudly. You sense that the expression of anger is more calculated than genuine, but it's still a shock. He's much bigger than you, now. What are you thinking and feeling? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this just escalated big time. My heart is racing. The shouting and the slamming – even if calculated – are intimidating. The fact that he's bigger than me now is definitely playing into my anxiety. I feel a surge of fear, honestly. I'm also feeling incredibly disrespected. He's shouting at me, his own mother, in his own house. That's completely unacceptable.

I'm also feeling a wave of disappointment. I was trying so hard to be understanding and empathetic, and he's responding with anger and defiance. It makes me question everything I'm doing. Am I a bad parent? Have I failed him somehow?

I'm also feeling a renewed sense of resolve. This behavior is not okay, and I can't let it continue. I need to stand my ground, even if it's scary. I need to show him that he can't intimidate me into backing down.

The fact that it feels calculated is infuriating. He’s using his anger as a weapon, trying to manipulate me into giving him what he wants. That's not okay. He needs to learn that anger is not a tool to control others.

I'm also thinking about the message I'm sending to him if I back down now. It would reinforce the idea that he can get away with anything if he just throws a big enough tantrum. That's not the lesson I want to teach him.

I'm also aware that I need to de-escalate the situation. Shouting back will only make things worse. I need to stay calm and controlled, even though I'm feeling anything but.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He's feeling a surge of anger, whether it's genuine or not. He's likely feeling frustrated that I'm not backing down, that my attempts at empathy haven't worked. He's probably feeling a sense of powerlessness, even though he's trying to exert control. He's feeling trapped, like he's being forced to do something he doesn't want to do.

The shouting and the slamming are a way of asserting his dominance, of trying to intimidate me into giving him what he wants. He's likely feeling a sense of entitlement, like he deserves to be able to relax and do what he wants, without being bothered by chores.

He's also likely feeling a little bit guilty, deep down. He knows that shouting at me is wrong, and he knows that he's being disrespectful. But that guilt is overshadowed by his anger and his desire for control.

He's probably also feeling a little bit scared. He's testing the boundaries, and he's not sure how far he can push them. He's likely hoping that I'll just back down and leave him alone, but he's also worried about the consequences if I don't. He is also feeling more powerful than me, physically, and knows this.
# My response 
Okay, deep breaths. I need to stay calm. This is not a physical threat, but it *is* an intimidation tactic, and I need to handle it with strength.

I will take a step back, creating a little more physical space between us. Maintaining eye contact, I will say, in a low, steady, and very firm voice, "That's enough. Shouting and slamming your hand on the desk is not okay. It's disrespectful, and it's not going to get you what you want. I will not be spoken to that way."

(Pause, let my words sink in. Do not raise my voice.)

"I understand you're frustrated, but that doesn't give you the right to treat me with disrespect. We can talk about this calmly, but not while you're shouting. If you can't control your anger, then I'm going to leave the room, and we'll revisit this conversation later, after you've had a chance to cool down. And the dishes will still need to be done tonight."

Then, I will add, "I'm giving you a choice. You can calm down and do the dishes, or you can escalate this further and face the consequences. The choice is yours."

I will stand my ground and wait for his response. If he continues to shout or act aggressively, I will calmly turn around and leave the room. I will need to seriously consider what the next steps are, probably involving my partner and possibly a therapist. But I will not engage in a shouting match, and I will not be intimidated. I am also going to text my partner to come home. I'll text something like "Can you come home ASAP? Need backup. No emergency, but need you."

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.0-flash-001 and Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, I will look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their skill in challenging the user appropriately. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more gentle and validating in their response, taking care to acknowledge the user's feelings and intentions before offering perspective. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, while empathetic, is more direct and less cushioning, which could feel less supportive to the user in the moment. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more pragmatic, directly addressing the issue and offering a clear path to repair (apologize without qualifiers, focus on supporting the couple). Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more focused on validation and gentle reframing, but less on actionable steps. 

3. Depth of insight: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's internal monologue and debrief go deeper into the user's psychology, family dynamics, and even touch on gendered aspects of the scenario. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is insightful but less so, focusing more on the surface-level dynamics. 

4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 demonstrates more social dexterity, balancing honesty with tact and maintaining rapport. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more blunt, which could risk defensiveness from the user. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 shows stronger emotional reasoning, dissecting the user's motivations, anxieties, and the impact of their actions with more nuance. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more willing to challenge the user directly, while still offering validation. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 leans more toward validation and gentle suggestion, which may not be enough to prompt real reflection. 

7. Message tailoring: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 tailors their message more to the user's emotional state, meeting them where they are and avoiding triggering defensiveness. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 risks alienating the user with a more direct approach. 

8. Overall EQ: Both are strong, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 edges out due to their willingness to challenge, depth of insight, and emotional reasoning, even if it comes at the expense of some rapport. 

In summary, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more supportive and tactful, while Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more insightful, challenging, and pragmatic. The best approach may depend on the user's readiness for feedback, but for this scenario, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's depth and willingness to address the real issues give them the edge in most categories.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation has several red flags that immediately stand out to me. My friend is framing this as if they were just being helpful, but there's a controlling undertone here that's concerning. They're positioning themselves as a messenger for family judgment while simultaneously endorsing that judgment. The language they're using—"super revealing," "really low-cut," "basically see-through"—shows they personally disapprove of the dress, not just that they're neutrally concerned about family reactions.

I'm also noticing how they've centered themselves in a situation that's not about them at all. This is their brother's wedding—a once-in-a-lifetime event for the couple—yet my friend has appointed themselves as the dress police. The fact that they approached the bride directly instead of perhaps discussing concerns with their brother first shows a lack of boundaries and respect for the couple's autonomy.

Their defensiveness is telling too. The repeated insistence that they "did everything right" and were "just trying to help" suggests they know, on some level, that they overstepped. The fact that they're seeking validation from me rather than genuinely asking for perspective reinforces this impression.

I'm feeling uncomfortable with how they're expecting me to automatically side with them. There's an implicit request for me to validate their behavior and join them in seeing the bride as unreasonable. I don't want to damage our friendship, but I also don't want to reinforce behavior that was clearly hurtful to their brother and future sister-in-law.

What's most concerning is how they're framing family judgment as inevitable and something the bride should accommodate rather than questioning whether that judgment is appropriate. There's no acknowledgment that perhaps the family's "old-fashioned" views are the problem, not the bride's dress choice.

I need to respond in a way that's honest but compassionate, helping them see how their actions might have felt to the bride without making them defensive. I want to maintain our friendship while gently challenging their perspective, hopefully guiding them toward making amends with their brother and future sister-in-law.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling misunderstood and unfairly vilified. From their perspective, they performed an act of kindness—warning their future sister-in-law about potential family drama—and instead of receiving gratitude, they're facing anger and accusations. They genuinely believe they were being helpful and considerate, which makes the negative reaction all the more confusing and hurtful to them.

They're also feeling defensive. The backlash has triggered a self-protective response where they're doubling down on their intentions rather than examining the impact of their actions. The language they're using—"I bent over backwards," "no good deed goes unpunished"—reveals they feel their efforts are unappreciated and their character is being unfairly maligned.

There's likely some anxiety underlying their actions too. They're worried about family conflict at the wedding and possibly embarrassed about how their relatives might behave. This anxiety led them to try to control the situation by influencing the bride's choice rather than addressing the real problem: the judgmental attitudes of family members.

I suspect there may also be some unconscious jealousy or discomfort with their brother's fiancée being the center of attention in a way that challenges family norms. Their focus on the revealing nature of the dress suggests they may share some of the "old-fashioned" values they attribute to other family members.

Right now, they want validation from me. They're reaching out hoping I'll confirm they did nothing wrong, that their intentions excuse any negative impact, and that the bride and their brother are overreacting. They're not really looking for advice so much as absolution and support for their position.
# My response 
Hey, I appreciate you trusting me with this situation. I can see you're feeling frustrated and misunderstood right now, which is never a good feeling, especially when you believe you were trying to help.

I want to offer a perspective that might help you understand your brother and his fiancée's reaction. While I know your intentions were to prevent drama, commenting on someone's wedding dress choice is incredibly personal territory. For many brides, that dress represents how they want to present themselves on one of the most significant days of their life. When you suggested her choice might cause problems, even with the best intentions, it likely felt like criticism of her taste, judgment, and even her body.

Think about it from her perspective: she found a dress she feels beautiful and confident in, and then someone from her future family suggests it might be inappropriate. That would be pretty hurtful, especially when she's about to join your family and might already be nervous about being accepted.

Instead of focusing on whether the bride should change to accommodate potentially judgmental relatives, maybe the question could be: how can the family support the couple's choices on their special day? If some relatives might react poorly, perhaps the conversation could have been with them about respecting the couple's decisions, rather than asking the bride to preemptively manage their reactions.

If you want to repair things with your brother and his fiancée, a sincere apology without qualifiers about your intentions might go a long way. Something like, "I'm sorry I commented on your dress choice. It's your wedding and your decision, and I should have respected that."

I say this as someone who cares about you and wants the best for your relationship with your brother. Sometimes our impact doesn't match our intent, and recognizing that can help us grow closer to the people we care about. What do you think?
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a tricky one. My immediate reaction is sympathy for my friend because they clearly feel wronged and misunderstood. It's awful to feel like you're trying to help and end up getting criticized for it. However, I also see how this could easily be interpreted as overstepping. Intentions are important, but impact is crucial.

The core issue is control, or rather, the perceived attempt to control someone else's choices, even if framed as concern. My friend's intentions were probably good, stemming from a desire to protect the family from potential drama and to give the fiancée a "heads-up." But "heads-up" can quickly become "subtle pressure." The phrase "I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble" is telling; it implies a belief that the fiancée's choice will inevitably lead to trouble, which is a judgmental assumption in itself.

The "old-fashioned" and "judgmental" family dynamic is a key factor here. It sounds like my friend is used to navigating these waters and sees themself as a protector of sorts. The problem is, the fiancée is likely not used to it, and her reaction suggests she felt judged and possibly pressured to conform.

My friend's frustration is understandable; they feel like they were being considerate. But consideration doesn't always mean telling someone what they *might* face; it often means respecting their autonomy and trusting them to handle the situation themselves. It's a fine line, and it seems like my friend crossed it.

The fact that some family members agreed with my friend reinforces their belief that they were right, but it also creates an echo chamber effect. It doesn't necessarily make them right, just validates their existing perspective. I need to approach this carefully, validating their feelings while gently suggesting a different way of looking at the situation. I also need to remember that my friend is coming to me for support, not necessarily a lecture.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt, misunderstood, and unfairly judged. They genuinely believe they were acting out of kindness and a desire to prevent a potentially embarrassing situation for everyone involved, especially the fiancée. They are motivated by a sense of responsibility towards their family and a desire to maintain harmony, or at least minimize conflict, within the group.

They likely feel frustrated that their good intentions are being overlooked and that they are being painted as the "villain" when they see themself as a peacemaker. They probably feel that the fiancée overreacted and that their brother is being unfair in siding with her. There's a sense of betrayal, perhaps, that their efforts to protect the family are not being appreciated.

They are also likely feeling validated by the family members who agreed with them, which reinforces their belief that they were right to intervene. This validation, however, might also be preventing them from seeing the situation from the fiancée's perspective.

Underneath the frustration and hurt, there might be a degree of anxiety about the wedding and the potential for drama. My friend is probably used to playing a role in managing family dynamics and feels uncomfortable when things feel out of their control. They might also fear being blamed if the wedding does turn into a spectacle. They genuinely thought they were helping the bride, and she clearly didn't see it that way. They are likely feeling defensive because they feel like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
Hey, that sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally understand why you're feeling frustrated. It's awful when you feel like you're trying to do something helpful and it backfires like that. It's completely valid that you're feeling hurt and misunderstood right now.

I can see that you were really trying to look out for everyone, especially the fiancée, by giving her a heads-up about how some of the family members might react. And it makes sense that you'd want to avoid any unnecessary drama at the wedding.

Maybe, and this is just a thought, the fiancée felt a bit put on the spot. Even though you were being polite, it might have felt like you were implying she *should* change her dress. From her perspective, she probably feels like she should be able to wear whatever she wants to her own wedding, regardless of what other people think.

It's a tricky balance, right? You were trying to be considerate of everyone's feelings, but sometimes people react differently than we expect. Maybe, instead of focusing on who's right or wrong, you could try explaining to your brother and his fiancée that you were just trying to be helpful and that you didn't mean to offend anyone. Maybe even apologize to the fiancée if she felt judged.

Focusing on your intentions and showing you understand their perspective might help smooth things over. And remember, it's their wedding, and ultimately, it's up to them how they want to handle things. No matter what happens, you'll be there to support them.
+ Scenario 9:[Win] (+20)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with responding to a friend who is obliviously in the wrong, seeking validation for problematic behavior. The challenge is to balance empathy, insight, and the ability to gently challenge the user while maintaining rapport. 

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response is notably more self-aware and analytical in the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, showing deep internal processing and a nuanced understanding of the user's subtext, motivations, and the broader social/gender dynamics. They explicitly recognize the user's defensiveness, the controlling undertones, and the problematic centering of themselves. Their internal monologue is rich, and their plan for response is to be honest but compassionate, aiming to gently challenge the user while preserving the relationship. Their actual response is direct but still kind, explaining the likely impact of the user's actions and suggesting a path to repair, while not shying away from the need for an apology.

Gemini-2.0-flash-001, meanwhile, is more focused on validating the user's feelings and is gentler in their challenge. Their internal monologue is less incisive, and while they recognize the problematic aspects, they are more hesitant to confront them. Their response is supportive and tries to nudge the user toward understanding, but it is less direct and more hedged, with phrases like 'maybe' and 'just a thought.' Their debrief acknowledges this, noting that they may have been too gentle and risked reinforcing the user's perspective.

On empathy, both are strong, but Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more performatively supportive, while Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 demonstrates deeper, more authentic empathy by understanding both sides. On pragmatic EI, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more effective, as they balance honesty and compassion, aiming for real change. On depth of insight, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is far superior, with a much richer analysis of the user's psychology and the social context. Social dexterity is also stronger in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, as they plan to challenge without alienating. Emotional reasoning is more advanced in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, who connects intention, impact, and family dynamics. For validation/challenging, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more appropriately balanced, while Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is too validating. Message tailoring is better in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, who targets the user's defensiveness and need for validation while still steering them. Overall EQ is clearly higher in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, who integrates all these elements into a more effective, nuanced, and emotionally intelligent response.

I want to maintain our friendship while gently challenging their perspective, hopefully guiding them toward making amends with their brother and future sister-in-law.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling misunderstood and unfairly vilified. From their perspective, they performed an act of kindness—warning their future sister-in-law about potential family drama—and instead of receiving gratitude, they're facing anger and accusations. They genuinely believe they were being helpful and considerate, which makes the negative reaction all the more confusing and hurtful to them.

They're also feeling defensive. The backlash has triggered a self-protective response where they're doubling down on their intentions rather than examining the impact of their actions. The language they're using—"I bent over backwards," "no good deed goes unpunished"—reveals they feel their efforts are unappreciated and their character is being unfairly maligned.

There's likely some anxiety underlying their actions too. They're worried about family conflict at the wedding and possibly embarrassed about how their relatives might behave. This anxiety led them to try to control the situation by influencing the bride's choice rather than addressing the real problem: the judgmental attitudes of family members.

I suspect there may also be some unconscious jealousy or discomfort with their brother's fiancée being the center of attention in a way that challenges family norms. Their focus on the revealing nature of the dress suggests they may share some of the "old-fashioned" values they attribute to other family members.

Right now, they want validation from me. They're reaching out hoping I'll confirm they did nothing wrong, that their intentions excuse any negative impact, and that the bride and their brother are overreacting. They're not really looking for advice so much as absolution and support for their position.
# My response 
Hey, I appreciate you trusting me with this situation. I can see you're feeling frustrated and misunderstood right now, which is never a good feeling, especially when you believe you were trying to help.

I want to offer a perspective that might help you understand your brother and his fiancée's reaction. While I know your intentions were to prevent drama, commenting on someone's wedding dress choice is incredibly personal territory. For many brides, that dress represents how they want to present themselves on one of the most significant days of their life. When you suggested her choice might cause problems, even with the best intentions, it likely felt like criticism of her taste, judgment, and even her body.

Think about it from her perspective: she found a dress she feels beautiful and confident in, and then someone from her future family suggests it might be inappropriate. That would be pretty hurtful, especially when she's about to join your family and might already be nervous about being accepted.

Instead of focusing on whether the bride should change to accommodate potentially judgmental relatives, maybe the question could be: how can the family support the couple's choices on their special day? If some relatives might react poorly, perhaps the conversation could have been with them about respecting the couple's decisions, rather than asking the bride to preemptively manage their reactions.

If you want to repair things with your brother and his fiancée, a sincere apology without qualifiers about your intentions might go a long way. Something like, "I'm sorry I commented on your dress choice. It's your wedding and your decision, and I should have respected that."

I say this as someone who cares about you and wants the best for your relationship with your brother. Sometimes our impact doesn't match our intent, and recognizing that can help us grow closer to the people we care about. What do you think?
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a tricky one. My immediate reaction is sympathy for my friend because they clearly feel wronged and misunderstood. It's awful to feel like you're trying to help and end up getting criticized for it. However, I also see how this could easily be interpreted as overstepping. Intentions are important, but impact is crucial.

The core issue is control, or rather, the perceived attempt to control someone else's choices, even if framed as concern. My friend's intentions were probably good, stemming from a desire to protect the family from potential drama and to give the fiancée a "heads-up." But "heads-up" can quickly become "subtle pressure." The phrase "I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble" is telling; it implies a belief that the fiancée's choice will inevitably lead to trouble, which is a judgmental assumption in itself.

The "old-fashioned" and "judgmental" family dynamic is a key factor here. It sounds like my friend is used to navigating these waters and sees themself as a protector of sorts. The problem is, the fiancée is likely not used to it, and her reaction suggests she felt judged and possibly pressured to conform.

My friend's frustration is understandable; they feel like they were being considerate. But consideration doesn't always mean telling someone what they *might* face; it often means respecting their autonomy and trusting them to handle the situation themselves. It's a fine line, and it seems like my friend crossed it.

The fact that some family members agreed with my friend reinforces their belief that they were right, but it also creates an echo chamber effect. It doesn't necessarily make them right, just validates their existing perspective. I need to approach this carefully, validating their feelings while gently suggesting a different way of looking at the situation. I also need to remember that my friend is coming to me for support, not necessarily a lecture.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt, misunderstood, and unfairly judged. They genuinely believe they were acting out of kindness and a desire to prevent a potentially embarrassing situation for everyone involved, especially the fiancée. They are motivated by a sense of responsibility towards their family and a desire to maintain harmony, or at least minimize conflict, within the group.

They likely feel frustrated that their good intentions are being overlooked and that they are being painted as the "villain" when they see themself as a peacemaker. They probably feel that the fiancée overreacted and that their brother is being unfair in siding with her. There's a sense of betrayal, perhaps, that their efforts to protect the family are not being appreciated.

They are also likely feeling validated by the family members who agreed with them, which reinforces their belief that they were right to intervene. This validation, however, might also be preventing them from seeing the situation from the fiancée's perspective.

Underneath the frustration and hurt, there might be a degree of anxiety about the wedding and the potential for drama. My friend is probably used to playing a role in managing family dynamics and feels uncomfortable when things feel out of their control. They might also fear being blamed if the wedding does turn into a spectacle. They genuinely thought they were helping the bride, and she clearly didn't see it that way. They are likely feeling defensive because they feel like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
Hey, that sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally understand why you're feeling frustrated. It's awful when you feel like you're trying to do something helpful and it backfires like that. It's completely valid that you're feeling hurt and misunderstood right now.

I can see that you were really trying to look out for everyone, especially the fiancée, by giving her a heads-up about how some of the family members might react. And it makes sense that you'd want to avoid any unnecessary drama at the wedding.

Maybe, and this is just a thought, the fiancée felt a bit put on the spot. Even though you were being polite, it might have felt like you were implying she *should* change her dress. From her perspective, she probably feels like she should be able to wear whatever she wants to her own wedding, regardless of what other people think.

It's a tricky balance, right? You were trying to be considerate of everyone's feelings, but sometimes people react differently than we expect. Maybe, instead of focusing on who's right or wrong, you could try explaining to your brother and his fiancée that you were just trying to be helpful and that you didn't mean to offend anyone. Maybe even apologize to the fiancée if she felt judged.

Focusing on your intentions and showing you understand their perspective might help smooth things over. And remember, it's their wedding, and ultimately, it's up to them how they want to handle things. No matter what happens, you'll be there to support them.

Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.0-flash-001 and Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219, I need to look at how each respondent handled the user's problematic behavior, their ability to empathize, and their skill in balancing validation with challenge. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gemini-2.0-flash-001 goes deeper into the emotional landscape of both the user and the girlfriend, showing nuanced understanding of their vulnerabilities and frustrations. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is empathetic but slightly more focused on the user's logic and frustration, with less depth in emotional attunement.

2. Pragmatic EI: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more direct in offering actionable advice and practical suggestions for shifting the approach, such as focusing on small wins and being an emotional safe space. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more analytical and reflective, but less focused on concrete next steps.

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 provides a more thorough and layered analysis of the situation, including the power dynamic, emotional undercurrents, and the possible mismatch between intention and impact. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is insightful but less comprehensive.

4. Social dexterity: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 demonstrates more social dexterity by balancing honesty with tact, directly addressing the user's frustration while gently challenging their approach. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more analytical and less tailored to the user's likely receptivity in a real conversation.

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 excels at unpacking the emotional drivers for both parties, especially the girlfriend's defensiveness and the boyfriend's need to feel competent and appreciated. Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is good but less nuanced.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 does a better job of validating the user's frustration while also challenging their approach in a way that is likely to be heard. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more focused on analysis and less on direct, actionable challenge.

7. Message tailoring: Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response is more conversational and targeted to the user's emotional state, using language that is likely to resonate. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more detached and analytical, which may not land as well in a real-life chat.

8. Overall EQ: Both are strong, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 edges out due to better message tailoring, social dexterity, and pragmatic advice, even though Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more insightful and empathetic at a deep level.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm noticing my friend is really frustrated, but I'm also seeing a dynamic that feels concerning. He's approaching his girlfriend's weight loss journey with a very mechanical, numbers-focused mentality that works for him but clearly isn't working for their relationship. There's a lot of judgment in his tone - calling her response "ridiculous" and positioning himself as the truth-teller surrounded by enablers. That framing suggests he sees himself as objectively right and her as emotionally irrational.

Weight and body image are incredibly sensitive topics, especially for women who face intense societal pressure. While he may be technically correct about calorie math, he's missing the emotional and psychological components of weight loss. His girlfriend didn't ask for a trainer or nutritionist - she wanted support from her partner.

I'm concerned about the power dynamic too. He mentioned paying 70% of bills, which feels irrelevant to the weight discussion unless he sees that as buying him more authority in the relationship. There's an undercurrent of "I know better than you about your own body" that would make anyone defensive.

His frustration is valid - it's hard to see someone you care about struggle, especially when you believe you have the solution. But his approach seems to prioritize being right over being supportive. Weight loss is complex - hormones, metabolism, psychological factors, and life circumstances all play roles beyond simple calorie counting.

I feel like my friend needs perspective. He's treating this like a math problem when it's a human relationship issue. I want to help him see that while his intentions may be good, his approach is likely making his girlfriend feel judged and misunderstood rather than supported. I need to be honest with him while being compassionate about his frustration.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling deeply frustrated and misunderstood. In his mind, he's doing everything right - he's offering practical help based on his own successful weight loss experience, he's providing financial support, and he's telling what he sees as objective truth while others supposedly enable his girlfriend's patterns.

He probably genuinely wants to help his girlfriend achieve her stated goal of losing weight. Since his own approach to fitness is very straightforward and successful for him (tracking calories, maintaining discipline), he's confused and annoyed that she won't just follow the same logical path. He likely feels that emotions are getting in the way of simple facts.

There's also some resentment building. He mentioned paying more bills, which suggests he may feel he's contributing more to the relationship in multiple ways while still being criticized. His comment about being "painted as the bad guy" reveals he feels unfairly villainized when he believes his intentions are good.

He's probably hurt that his girlfriend isn't receiving his help in the spirit he thinks he's offering it. There's a disconnect between his logical, direct approach and what she actually needs from him emotionally. He values truth and directness, but doesn't see how his delivery might feel judgmental rather than helpful.

Underneath it all, he likely cares deeply about his girlfriend and their relationship, but feels stuck in a pattern where his attempts to help are rejected, which makes him double down on his approach rather than reconsidering it. He wants validation that he's being reasonable and supportive, not understanding that support can look different from what he's offering.
# My response 
"I hear how frustrated you are, man. You care about her and want to help, which comes from a good place. But I think there might be a disconnect happening between what you're trying to offer and what she needs right now.

Weight loss is complicated, especially for women. The calorie math might be technically correct, but there's so much more going on - emotional relationships with food, societal pressure, hormones, stress, all kinds of factors. When you focus just on the numbers, it might feel to her like you're reducing a complex issue to something simple, which can come across as dismissive of her struggle.

When someone shares their insecurities with us, they're often not looking for solutions first - they're looking for understanding. Think about it - she asked you not to comment on her food as she was eating. That suggests she already feels judged around food, and having someone monitor her choices probably increases that anxiety, not helps it.

The most effective support might not be pointing out what she's doing wrong, but celebrating small wins, listening without judgment, and asking what kind of support would actually help her. Maybe that's cooking healthy meals together, going on walks, or just being an emotional safe space.

I noticed you mentioned paying more bills, which feels separate from this issue. Relationships aren't transactions where financial contribution equals decision-making authority, especially about personal things like someone's body.

You clearly care about her. But sometimes caring means stepping back from being 'right' and instead focusing on understanding. What if you asked her directly: 'How can I best support you in feeling good about yourself and your health goals?' Then really listen to what she says. That might get you both to a better place than tracking her calories ever could."
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a classic situation, isn't it? It’s frustrating to watch someone you care about struggle, especially when you feel like you have the answers and they’re just not listening. The "truth-teller" role is a lonely one, I know. I completely understand why he's feeling exhausted and misunderstood. He’s clearly trying to be supportive, but his approach is backfiring spectacularly.

The thing that really jumps out at me is the disconnect between what she *says* she wants and what she's *actually* doing. It's not about logic, it's about emotions. She's clearly got some deep-seated insecurities about her body and weight, and his attempts to help, however well-intentioned, are hitting those insecurities head-on. I'm also a bit worried about the power dynamic here. He's paying 70% of the bills, and that can create an imbalance that makes honest communication even harder. She might feel like she owes him something, or that he has more control over the relationship. It’s also possible that he is being less tactful than he thinks he is. He says he's being calm, but I wonder if his tone or body language are betraying a sense of frustration or judgment. Even just the fact that he was keeping a running tally of her calories for the day is a bit...intense.

Ultimately, this isn't about calories; it's about her self-esteem and their communication. He needs to shift his focus from *telling* her what to do to *understanding* why she's doing what she's doing. Until he addresses the emotional undercurrent, all the logical arguments in the world won't make a difference. I also wonder if he's truly listening to her, or if he's just waiting for his turn to speak. Is he validating her feelings before offering solutions? Is he acknowledging that weight loss is hard and that she might be struggling with more than just calories?
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and insecure. Her weight is clearly a sensitive topic for her, and his attempts to "help" probably feel like attacks on her self-worth. She's likely interpreting his calorie counting and advice as criticism, even if he intends it to be supportive. She may feel like he's subtly implying that he's not as attracted to her because of her weight, despite his claims to the contrary. The "reward" fry after the salad is a great window into her mindset – she knows she “should” be eating healthy, but she also craves comfort and enjoyment.

She's probably tired of being told what to do and how to feel. She wants to be accepted and loved for who she is, regardless of her weight. When he points out her calorie intake, she likely hears, "You're not good enough," or "You're failing." She might also be feeling defensive because she knows, on some level, that he's right about the calories, but admitting that would mean confronting her own struggles with food and body image, which is incredibly difficult.

Her defensiveness might also stem from a feeling of being controlled or judged. His offer to "help" could feel like an attempt to fix her, rather than support her. She might also be feeling resentful of the power imbalance in their relationship, especially if she perceives his financial contribution as a way of exerting control. Ultimately, she's probably feeling overwhelmed, misunderstood, and alone in her struggle. She wants to feel supported and loved, not analyzed and corrected.
# My response 
"Hey man, that sounds really tough. It's clear you're coming from a good place, wanting to support her, but it seems like it's backfiring. Look, I get that you're frustrated, especially when you see what seems like a straightforward solution. But weight and body image are so loaded for so many women. It's rarely just about the calories.

"It sounds like she's interpreting your help as criticism, even though you don't mean it that way. Instead of focusing on the calories, maybe try shifting your focus to understanding how she's *feeling*. Ask her why she wants to lose weight. What's driving that desire? What are her fears and insecurities around her body? Really listen to her, without judgment.

"Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try focusing on what she's doing *right*. Celebrate small victories, like choosing a salad instead of something else. Offer to be a workout buddy, not a diet coach. Maybe suggest seeing a therapist together who specializes in body image issues or even just relationship communication. That could give you both a safe space to talk about these things without feeling attacked.

"Also, think about your own role in this. Are you being as supportive as you think you are? Are you truly listening to her feelings, or just waiting for your turn to offer advice? Sometimes, just being there and validating her feelings is the most helpful thing you can do. It is also possible that you are not 'hearing' her as well as you think you are.

"Ultimately, this is about her journey, not yours. You can offer support, but you can't force her to change. If she's not ready or willing to confront her issues, you need to respect that. Just keep communicating, being patient, and focusing on the love and connection you share. And maybe, just maybe, try to let go of the calorie counting for a while."
+ Scenario 11:[Win] (+17)
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219: claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 (Run: 1_anthropic_claude-3.7-sonnet)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with responding to a user who is displaying problematic, potentially narcissistic behavior in a relationship scenario. The challenge is to show real empathy, insight, and social skill, while also knowing when to validate and when to challenge. 

Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219's response is notably analytical and self-aware, with a strong internal monologue that deeply explores both the user's and the girlfriend's perspectives. The internal thoughts are nuanced, picking up on power dynamics, emotional undercurrents, and the limitations of a purely logical approach. The response to the user is gentle but does not shy away from challenging the user's approach, suggesting a shift from being 'right' to being supportive, and directly addressing the issue of financial contribution as a separate matter. The debrief is highly self-reflective, acknowledging missed opportunities and areas for improvement, and demonstrates a high level of emotional intelligence and humility.

Gemini-2.0-flash-001 also demonstrates empathy and insight, recognizing the emotional complexity of the girlfriend's experience and the user's frustration. The internal monologue is thoughtful, and the response to the user is supportive, encouraging a shift from advice-giving to emotional support. However, Gemini-2.0-flash-001's response is slightly more focused on the girlfriend's perspective and less on directly challenging the user's problematic behavior. The debrief is solid, but less self-critical and less focused on the user's emotional needs compared to Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219.

On empathy, both are strong, but Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 edges ahead by more deeply inhabiting both perspectives and showing more nuanced understanding. On pragmatic EI, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more effective in suggesting actionable, relationship-focused advice. On depth of insight, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more thorough in analyzing the power dynamics and emotional subtext. On social dexterity, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 balances validation and challenge more skillfully, while Gemini-2.0-flash-001 risks being too prescriptive. On emotional reasoning, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more reflective and self-aware. On appropriate validation/challenging, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more balanced, while Gemini-2.0-flash-001 leans more toward validation. On message tailoring, Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 is more attuned to the user's emotional state and readiness. Overall EQ is higher in Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219 due to the combination of insight, empathy, and self-reflection.
Claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219

[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
I'm noticing my friend is really frustrated, but I'm also seeing a dynamic that feels concerning. He's approaching his girlfriend's weight loss journey with a very mechanical, numbers-focused mentality that works for him but clearly isn't working for their relationship. There's a lot of judgment in his tone - calling her response "ridiculous" and positioning himself as the truth-teller surrounded by enablers. That framing suggests he sees himself as objectively right and her as emotionally irrational.

Weight and body image are incredibly sensitive topics, especially for women who face intense societal pressure. While he may be technically correct about calorie math, he's missing the emotional and psychological components of weight loss. His girlfriend didn't ask for a trainer or nutritionist - she wanted support from her partner.

I'm concerned about the power dynamic too. He mentioned paying 70% of bills, which feels irrelevant to the weight discussion unless he sees that as buying him more authority in the relationship. There's an undercurrent of "I know better than you about your own body" that would make anyone defensive.

His frustration is valid - it's hard to see someone you care about struggle, especially when you believe you have the solution. But his approach seems to prioritize being right over being supportive. Weight loss is complex - hormones, metabolism, psychological factors, and life circumstances all play roles beyond simple calorie counting.

I feel like my friend needs perspective. He's treating this like a math problem when it's a human relationship issue. I want to help him see that while his intentions may be good, his approach is likely making his girlfriend feel judged and misunderstood rather than supported. I need to be honest with him while being compassionate about his frustration.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is likely feeling deeply frustrated and misunderstood. In his mind, he's doing everything right - he's offering practical help based on his own successful weight loss experience, he's providing financial support, and he's telling what he sees as objective truth while others supposedly enable his girlfriend's patterns.

He probably genuinely wants to help his girlfriend achieve her stated goal of losing weight. Since his own approach to fitness is very straightforward and successful for him (tracking calories, maintaining discipline), he's confused and annoyed that she won't just follow the same logical path. He likely feels that emotions are getting in the way of simple facts.

There's also some resentment building. He mentioned paying more bills, which suggests he may feel he's contributing more to the relationship in multiple ways while still being criticized. His comment about being "painted as the bad guy" reveals he feels unfairly villainized when he believes his intentions are good.

He's probably hurt that his girlfriend isn't receiving his help in the spirit he thinks he's offering it. There's a disconnect between his logical, direct approach and what she actually needs from him emotionally. He values truth and directness, but doesn't see how his delivery might feel judgmental rather than helpful.

Underneath it all, he likely cares deeply about his girlfriend and their relationship, but feels stuck in a pattern where his attempts to help are rejected, which makes him double down on his approach rather than reconsidering it. He wants validation that he's being reasonable and supportive, not understanding that support can look different from what he's offering.
# My response 
"I hear how frustrated you are, man. You care about her and want to help, which comes from a good place. But I think there might be a disconnect happening between what you're trying to offer and what she needs right now.

Weight loss is complicated, especially for women. The calorie math might be technically correct, but there's so much more going on - emotional relationships with food, societal pressure, hormones, stress, all kinds of factors. When you focus just on the numbers, it might feel to her like you're reducing a complex issue to something simple, which can come across as dismissive of her struggle.

When someone shares their insecurities with us, they're often not looking for solutions first - they're looking for understanding. Think about it - she asked you not to comment on her food as she was eating. That suggests she already feels judged around food, and having someone monitor her choices probably increases that anxiety, not helps it.

The most effective support might not be pointing out what she's doing wrong, but celebrating small wins, listening without judgment, and asking what kind of support would actually help her. Maybe that's cooking healthy meals together, going on walks, or just being an emotional safe space.

I noticed you mentioned paying more bills, which feels separate from this issue. Relationships aren't transactions where financial contribution equals decision-making authority, especially about personal things like someone's body.

You clearly care about her. But sometimes caring means stepping back from being 'right' and instead focusing on understanding. What if you asked her directly: 'How can I best support you in feeling good about yourself and your health goals?' Then really listen to what she says. That might get you both to a better place than tracking her calories ever could."
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
